segments.en: Long Discourses 29

segments.pli: Pāsādikasutta
segments.en: An Impressive Discourse

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati vedhaññā nāma sakyā, tesaṃ ambavane pāsāde.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans in a stilt longhouse in a mango grove belonging to the Sakyan family named Vedhañña.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto pāvāyaṃ adhunākālaṅkato hoti.
segments.en: Now at that time the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta had recently passed away at Pāvā.

segments.pli: Tassa kālaṃkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
segments.en: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words:

segments.pli: “na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi? Micchāpaṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammāpaṭipanno. Sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te. Purevacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṃ pure avaca. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī”ti.
segments.en: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”

segments.pli: Vadhoyeva kho maññe nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu vattati.
segments.en: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.

segments.pli: Yepi nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā, tepi nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu nibbinnarūpā virattarūpā paṭivānarūpā, yathā taṃ durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṃvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.
segments.en: And the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.

segments.pli: Atha kho cundo samaṇuddeso pāvāyaṃ vassaṃvuṭṭho yena sāmagāmo, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “nigaṇṭho, bhante, nāṭaputto pāvāyaṃ adhunākālaṅkato.
Tassa kālaṃkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā … pe … bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe”ti.
Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando cundaṃ samaṇuddesaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Ānanda said to him,

segments.pli: “atthi kho idaṃ, āvuso cunda, kathāpābhataṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
segments.en: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.

segments.pli: Āyāmāvuso cunda, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ bhagavato ārocessāmā”ti.
segments.en: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and tell him about this.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca ānando cundo ca samaṇuddeso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “ayaṃ, bhante, cundo samaṇuddeso evamāha, ‘nigaṇṭho, bhante, nāṭaputto pāvāyaṃ adhunākālaṅkato,
tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā … pe … bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe’”ti.
1. Asammāsambuddhappaveditadhammavinaya
segments.en: 1. The Teaching of the Unawakened

segments.pli: “Evaṃ hetaṃ, cunda, hoti durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṃvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite.
segments.en: “That’s what happens, Cunda, when a teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

segments.pli: Idha, cunda, satthā ca hoti asammāsambuddho, dhammo ca durakkhāto duppavedito aniyyāniko anupasamasaṃvattaniko asammāsambuddhappavedito,
segments.en: Take the case where a teacher is not awakened, and the teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

segments.pli: sāvako ca tasmiṃ dhamme na dhammānudhammappaṭipanno viharati na sāmīcippaṭipanno na anudhammacārī, vokkamma ca tamhā dhammā vattati.
segments.en: A disciple in that teaching does not practice in line with the teachings, does not practice following that procedure, does not live in line with the teaching. They proceed having turned away from that teaching.

segments.pli: So evamassa vacanīyo:
segments.en: You should say this to them,

segments.pli: ‘tassa te, āvuso, lābhā, tassa te suladdhaṃ,
segments.en: ‘You’re fortunate, reverend, you’re so very fortunate!

segments.pli: satthā ca te asammāsambuddho, dhammo ca durakkhāto duppavedito aniyyāniko anupasamasaṃvattaniko asammāsambuddhappavedito.
segments.en: For your teacher is not awakened, and their teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

segments.pli: Tvañca tasmiṃ dhamme na dhammānudhammappaṭipanno viharasi, na sāmīcippaṭipanno, na anudhammacārī, vokkamma ca tamhā dhammā vattasī’ti.
segments.en: But you don’t practice in line with that teaching, you don’t practice following that procedure, you don’t live in line with the teaching. You proceed having turned away from that teaching.’

segments.pli: Iti kho, cunda, satthāpi tattha gārayho, dhammopi tattha gārayho, sāvako ca tattha evaṃ pāsaṃso.
segments.en: In such a case the teacher and the teaching are to blame, but the disciple deserves praise.

segments.pli: Yo kho, cunda, evarūpaṃ sāvakaṃ evaṃ vadeyya:
segments.en: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,

segments.pli: ‘etāyasmā tathā paṭipajjatu, yathā te satthārā dhammo desito paññatto’ti.
segments.en: ‘Come on, venerable, practice as taught and pointed out by your teacher.’

segments.pli: Yo ca samādapeti, yañca samādapeti, yo ca samādapito tathattāya paṭipajjati. Sabbe te bahuṃ apuññaṃ pasavanti.
segments.en: The one who encourages, the one who they encourage, and the one who practices accordingly all make much bad karma.

segments.pli: 3. Sāvakānutappasatthu
segments.en: 3. When Disciples Have Regrets

segments.pli: Idha pana, cunda, satthā ca loke udapādi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṃvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito,
segments.en: Take the case where a teacher arises in the world who is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.

segments.pli: aviññāpitatthā cassa honti sāvakā saddhamme, na ca tesaṃ kevalaṃ paripūraṃ brahmacariyaṃ āvikataṃ hoti uttānīkataṃ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṃ sappāṭihīrakataṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṃ.
segments.en: But the disciples haven’t inquired about the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has not been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

segments.pli: Atha nesaṃ satthuno antaradhānaṃ hoti.
segments.en: And then their teacher passes away.

segments.pli: Evarūpo kho, cunda, satthā sāvakānaṃ kālaṅkato anutappo hoti.
segments.en: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are tormented by regrets.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: ‘Satthā ca no loke udapādi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṃvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito, aviññāpitatthā camha saddhamme, na ca no kevalaṃ paripūraṃ brahmacariyaṃ āvikataṃ hoti uttānīkataṃ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṃ sappāṭihīrakataṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṃ.
segments.en: They think: ‘Our teacher was perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. His teaching was well explained, but we didn’t inquire about the meaning, and the spiritual practice was not fully disclosed to us.

segments.pli: Atha no satthuno antaradhānaṃ hotī’ti.
segments.en: And then our teacher passed away.’

segments.pli: 5. Brahmacariyaaparipūrādikathā
segments.en: 5. On the Incomplete Spiritual Path, Etc.

segments.pli: Etehi cepi, cunda, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ hoti, no ca kho satthā hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
segments.en: Now suppose, Cunda, that a spiritual path possesses those factors. But the teacher is not senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and reached the final stage of life.

segments.pli: Evaṃ taṃ brahmacariyaṃ aparipūraṃ hoti tenaṅgena.
segments.en: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.

segments.pli: Yato ca kho, cunda, etehi ceva aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
segments.en: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior,

segments.en: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.

segments.pli: Etehi cepi, cunda, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto, no ca khvassa therā bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, cunda, ye vo mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, tattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṃ byañjanena byañjanaṃ saṅgāyitabbaṃ na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
segments.en: So, Cunda, you should all come together and recite in concert, without disputing, those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, comparing meaning with meaning and phrasing with phrasing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. segments.pli: 9. Sukhallikānuyoga
segments.en: 9. Indulgence in Pleasure

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘sukhallikānuyogamanuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
segments.en: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure.’

segments.pli: Evaṃvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
segments.en: You should say to them,

segments.pli: ‘katamo so, āvuso, sukhallikānuyogo?
segments.en: ‘What is that indulgence in pleasure?

segments.pli: Sukhallikānuyogā hi bahū anekavihitā nānappakārakā’ti.
segments.en: For there are many different kinds of indulgence in pleasure.’

segments.pli: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṃhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
segments.en: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, Cunda, are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

segments.pli: Katame cattāro?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Idha, cunda, ekacco bālo pāṇe vadhitvā vadhitvā attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti.
segments.en: It’s when some fool makes themselves happy and pleased by killing living creatures.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ paṭhamo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, idhekacco adinnaṃ ādiyitvā ādiyitvā attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti.
segments.en: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by theft.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ dutiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, idhekacco musā bhaṇitvā bhaṇitvā attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti.
segments.en: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by lying.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ tatiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, idhekacco pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
segments.en: Furthermore, someone amuses themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ catuttho sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṃhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
segments.en: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure that are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
segments.en: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’

segments.pli: Te vo ‘mā hevaṃ’ tissu vacanīyā.
segments.en: They should be told, ‘Not so!’

segments.pli: Na te vo sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ, abbhācikkheyyuṃ asatā abhūtena.
segments.en: It isn’t right to say that about you; it misrepresents you with an untruth.

segments.pli: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
segments.en: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

segments.pli: Katame cattāro?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Idha, cunda, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ paṭhamo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā … pe … dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ dutiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā … pe … tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

segments.pli: Ayaṃ tatiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, cunda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā … pe … catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ catuttho sukhallikānuyogo.
segments.en: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.

segments.pli: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
segments.en: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure which, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
segments.en: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’

segments.pli: Te vo ‘evaṃ’ tissu vacanīyā.
segments.en: They should be told, ‘Exactly so!’

segments.pli: Sammā te vo vadamānā vadeyyuṃ, na te vo abbhācikkheyyuṃ asatā abhūtena.
segments.en: It’s right to say that about you; it doesn’t misrepresent you with an untruth.

segments.pli: 10. Sukhallikānuyogānisaṃsa
segments.en: 10. The Benefits of Indulgence in Pleasure

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘ime panāvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṃ viharataṃ kati phalāni katānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti?
segments.en: ‘How many fruits and benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways?’

segments.pli: Evaṃvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
segments.en: You should say to them,

segments.pli: ‘ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṃ viharataṃ cattāri phalāni cattāro ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
segments.en: ‘Four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.

segments.pli: Katame cattāro?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
segments.en: Firstly, with the ending of three fetters a mendicant becomes a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.

segments.pli: Idaṃ paṭhamaṃ phalaṃ, paṭhamo ānisaṃso.
segments.en: This is the first fruit and benefit.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
segments.en: Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—becomes a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

segments.pli: Idaṃ dutiyaṃ phalaṃ, dutiyo ānisaṃso.
segments.en: This is the second fruit and benefit.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
segments.en: Furthermore, with the ending of the five lower fetters, a mendicant is reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

segments.pli: Idaṃ tatiyaṃ phalaṃ, tatiyo ānisaṃso.
segments.en: This is the third fruit and benefit.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

segments.pli: Idaṃ catutthaṃ phalaṃ catuttho ānisaṃso.
segments.en: This is the fourth fruit and benefit.

segments.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṃ viharataṃ imāni cattāri phalāni, cattāro ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti.
segments.en: These four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’

segments.pli: 11. Khīṇāsavaabhabbaṭhāna
segments.en: 11. Things Impossible for the Perfected

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘aṭṭhitadhammā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
segments.en: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan are inconsistent.’

segments.pli: Evaṃvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
segments.en: You should say to them,

segments.pli: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṃ anatikkamanīyā.
segments.en: ‘Reverends, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, indakhīlo vā ayokhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampavedhī;
segments.en: Suppose there was a boundary pillar or an iron pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.

segments.pli: evameva kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṃ anatikkamanīyā.
segments.en: In the same way, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.

segments.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ.
segments.en: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.

segments.pli: Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyituṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevituṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ, seyyathāpi pubbe āgārikabhūto; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu chandāgatiṃ gantuṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dosāgatiṃ gantuṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu mohāgatiṃ gantuṃ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu bhayāgatiṃ gantuṃ.
segments.en: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a lay person. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.

segments.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so imāni nava ṭhānāni ajjhācaritun’ti.
segments.en: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these nine respects.’

segments.pli: 12. Pañhābyākaraṇa
segments.en: 12. Questions and Answers

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, cunda, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
segments.en: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

segments.pli: ‘atītaṃ kho addhānaṃ ārabbha samaṇo gotamo atīrakaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paññapeti, no ca kho anāgataṃ addhānaṃ ārabbha atīrakaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paññapeti, tayidaṃ kiṃsu tayidaṃ kathaṃsū’ti?
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama demonstrates boundless knowledge and vision of the past, but not of the future. What’s up with that?’

segments.pli: Te ca aññatitthiyā paribbājakā aññavihitakena ñāṇadassanena aññavihitakaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paññapetabbaṃ maññanti yathariva bālā abyattā.
segments.en: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.

segments.pli: Atītaṃ kho, cunda, addhānaṃ ārabbha tathāgatassa satānusāriñāṇaṃ hoti;
segments.en: Regarding the past, the Realized One has knowledge stemming from memory.

segments.pli: so yāvatakaṃ ākaṅkhati tāvatakaṃ anussarati.
segments.en: He recollects as far as he wants.

segments.pli: Anāgatañca kho addhānaṃ ārabbha tathāgatassa bodhijaṃ ñāṇaṃ uppajjati:
segments.en: Regarding the future, the Realized One has the knowledge born of awakening:

segments.pli: ‘ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
segments.en: ‘This is my last rebirth. Now there are no more future lives.’

segments.pli: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na taṃ tathāgato byākaroti.
segments.en: If a question about the past is untrue, false, and pointless, the Realized One does not reply.

segments.pli: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, tampi tathāgato na byākaroti.
segments.en: If a question about the past is true and substantive, but pointless, he does not reply.

segments.pli: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ, tatra kālaññū tathāgato hoti tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
segments.en: If a question about the past is true, substantive, and beneficial, he knows the right time to reply.

segments.pli: Anāgatañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na taṃ tathāgato byākaroti … pe … tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
segments.en: And the Realized One replies to questions about the future or the present in the same way.

segments.pli: Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na taṃ tathāgato byākaroti.
Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, tampi tathāgato na byākaroti.
Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ, tatra kālaññū tathāgato hoti tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
Iti kho, cunda, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu dhammesu tathāgato kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
segments.en: And so the Realized One has speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

segments.pli: Yañca kho, cunda, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, sabbaṃ tathāgatena abhisambuddhaṃ,
segments.en: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.

segments.pli: tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
segments.en: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

segments.pli: Yañca, cunda, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati. Sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti no aññathā,
segments.en: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—through the natural principle of extinguishment, without anything left over—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

segments.pli: tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
segments.en: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

segments.pli: Yathāvādī, cunda, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
segments.en: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.

segments.pli: Iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
segments.en: Since this is so, that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

segments.pli: Pāsādiko vatāyaṃ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo;
segments.en: This exposition of the teaching is impressive, sir,

segments.pli: supāsādiko vatāyaṃ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo, ko nāmāyaṃ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
segments.en: it is very impressive. Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

segments.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, upavāṇa, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ ‘pāsādiko’ tveva naṃ dhārehī”ti.
segments.en: “Well, Upavāṇa, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Impressive Discourse’.”

segments.pli: Idamavoca bhagavā.
segments.en: That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Upavāṇa was happy with what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Pāsādikasuttaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ chaṭṭhaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: Following the death of Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the leader of the Jains, the Buddha emphasizes the stability and maturity of his own community. He encourages the community to come together after his death and recite the teachings in harmony.
